headline: Ask HN: How to Hold Someone Accountable?
description:
I'm a first time tech lead (CTO, but functionally more of a tech lead) at a start up and I've been struggling with the advice of "holding someone accountable".

My vision for culture was to use a KanBan process so that we could quickly iterate, be agile, and set up a sustainable workload. Mostly using Eric Brechner's "is this task less than 5 days?" to break work down and put it on the board.

So far this has worked out well for 3 developers on the team -- they work hard, communicate often, and really try to push the ball down the field every day. Code is checked in on a daily / every other day basis and overall have a high degree of "accountability" to work hard every day.

We brought on a senior backend developer in May who had previously worked at a bank for 10 years. He was meant to be a key hire to take over on some of my involvement with the backend codebase (note that I am not the original author, it was originally written by a previous contracting house). Overall I would describe him as "okay" -- has been slow on his tasks ("is this less than 5 days" = 5 days), overshooting timelines that he gives (everything is always "1 or 2 days away") , and "okay" quality.

- I'm a developer and understand that there is an element of "it takes as long as it takes", but I want to start thinking in days instead of weeks for tasks

- I had a 1-on-1 with him today and he describe it as "relaxed" which is definitely not how I've been feeling

I'm not quite sure what to do in this situation -- clearly there is an element of mismanagement on my end, but there is also an element of "this person is not driven like the rest of the team" that I don't quite know how to handle. How do you determine how much is your own failure as a manager, versus how much is someone just "not working out"?

- Do I just need to get really specific about asking "how long will this take" for every task and then trying to hold his feet to the fire when we get there? What does this look like?

    - "You said 2 days ago that it would be done in 1-2 days, what's going on?" What if they come up with excuses?

    - I have an agreeable personality which I am trying to overcome, and so am trying to figure out how to navigate conflict in a healthy way
Any help / resource recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
headline_zh-Hans: Ask HN: 如何追究某人的责任？
headline_zh-Hant: Ask HN: 如何追究某人的責任？
description_zh-Hans:
我是一家初创公司的第一次技术领导（CTO，但在职能上更像是技术领导），我一直在为"让某人负责"的建议而挣扎。

我对文化的设想是使用KanBan流程，这样我们可以快速迭代、敏捷，并建立一个可持续的工作量。

到目前为止，团队中的三名开发人员的工作情况良好--他们努力工作，经常沟通，并且每天都在努力推动球的发展。

我们在5月份引进了一位高级后台开发人员，他之前在一家银行工作了10年，他的代码是每天/隔天检查的，总的来说，他有高度的"责任感"，每天努力工作。他是一个关键的雇员，负责接管我参与的一些后端代码库（注意，我不是原作者，它最初是由以前的承包公司编写的）。总的来说，我想用"还行"来形容他 -- 他的任务进展缓慢（"这是不是少于5天"=5天），超出了他给出的时间表（一切总是"1或2天后"），而且"质量还行"。

- 我是一名开发人员，理解有一个 "需要多久就多久 "的因素，但我想开始用几天而不是几周来考虑任务

- 我今天和他进行了1对1交流，他把它描述为 "轻松"。这绝对不是我一直以来的感觉

我不太确定在这种情况下该怎么做--显然，我这边有管理不善的因素，但也有"这个人不像团队其他成员那样有动力"的因素，我不太知道如何处理。How do you determine how much is your own failure as a manager, versus how much is someone just "not working out"?

- Do I just need to get really specific about asking "how long will this take" for every task and then trying to hold his feet to the fire when we get there? What does this look like?

 - "You said 2 days ago that it would be done in 1-2 days, what's going on?" What if they come up with excuses?

    - I have an agreeable personality which I am trying to overcome, and so am trying to figure out how to navigate conflict in a healthy way
Any help / resource recommendations would be greatly appreciated!
